journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Crashworthiness design optimization using equivalent static loads

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Ansan City, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, 1271 Sa 3-dong, Sangnok-gu, Ansan City, Gyeonggi-do 426-791, Republic of Korea. email: gjpark@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: Crashworthiness is an issue that should be considered when designing a passenger vehicle to ensure the occupants’ safety in a vehicle accident. Many governments and insurance companies around the world suggest conditions relating to passenger safety in designing vehicles, and regulations that include the conditions have been utilized. The suggested regulations reflect the crashworthiness of structures in order to consider passenger safety. Therefore, these conditions should be used as objective functions or constraints when optimizing a vehicle structure. However, it is difficult to apply gradient-based optimization methods to crash optimization problems because of the large non-linearities of the problems which should be considered in the time domain. The non-linearities and oscillation of the responses make it difficult to calculate the sensitivity information. Therefore, a design method regarding the crash optimization problem needs to be developed. A crash problem should consider the crashworthiness of the vehicle. That is, a design problem should be solved regarding the crash energy conveyed from the outside and injuries to the human body. In the present research, a crashworthiness design optimization method using equivalent static loads that considers the strain energy and injuries of the human body is proposed. The equivalent static loads method for non-linear static response structural optimization (ESLSO) is modified to handle responses imposed on the strain energy and the head injury criterion (HIC) responses. The proposed ESLSO is verified through three practical examples. Design optimization of a crash box and a knee bolster are carried out to maximize absorbed impact energy, and size optimization of a frontal structure of a simplified vehicle is performed to reduce head injury. In verifying the proposed method, traditional optimization methods such as the response surface method are used. The excellence and usefulness of the proposed crashworthiness optimization method are proved by successfully applying it to a crash problem and improving the crashworthiness of the vehicle.

kwd-group.kwd: equivalent static loads method for non-linear static response structural optimization (ESLSO)

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The ability to absorb impact energy and be survivable for the occupant is called the ‘crashworthiness’ of the structure in passenger vehicles [1]. Therefore, a way to calculate the injuries of passengers and absorbed impact energy is needed in a vehicle accident. In designing the vehicle structure, crashworthiness of the structure is an important matter, so that passengers survive in an accident. In general, space for absorbing the impact energy and additional parts are needed to increase the crashworthiness of a structure. Additional space and parts increase the production cost and make it difficult to achieve a lightweight body. Many governments around the world establish regulations reflecting the crashworthiness of structures in order to consider passenger safety [2, 3]. Moreover, insurance companies induce consumers to choose a safer car by announcing the repair cost of each vehicle based on the suggested test conditions reflecting the vehicle accident [4, 5].

Crash analyses are performed for calculating the crashworthiness of the structure under the test conditions for occupant safety. The responses of the crash analyses are of various types relating to injury of the human body and the impact energy absorbed by the vehicle. Computer simulation using the finite element method (FEM) is well developed and widely used to consider the dynamic effect and large non-linearity of crash analyses [6–8]. In general, a crash problem combines the effect of large non-linearities with the fact that a single model evaluation can be computationally very expensive. In considering the crashworthiness problem, stochastic and approximation optimization methods are often applied these days. These methods use the approximation function based on some candidate points, but model evaluations can be very expensive computationally to build the function. Moreover, the large non-linearities of crash analysis make it difficult to calculate the sensitivity information in applying conventional design methods to a crashworthiness optimization problem [9–11]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a new optimization method for crash analysis while considering the various types of response.

After Lust suggested an optimization formulation with the crashworthiness constraints and stiffness of a vehicle structure [12], several works were conducted on the crashworthiness optimization of vehicle structures. However, most researchers proposed non-gradient-based optimization methods such as the response surface method (RSM) to solve the crash problem [13, 14]. The responses of the crash problem are approximated to mathematical equations based on the responses of sampling points. Therefore, the method can be easily applied to practical problems and accommodate various types of crash analysis response. However, it is difficult to solve a problem with many design variables because a large number of crash analyses are required for generation of an approximate model. Moreover, the optimum results may not be exact because an approximated model is utilized. Recently, various approaches have been developed for crashworthiness optimization problems. Youn et al. applied the reliability-based optimization method using the response surface function to the vehicle side-impact problem [15]. Acar and Solanki proposed the system-reliability-based optimization method for crashworthiness to reduce the uncertainty of responses in both the frontal- and side-impact test problem [16]. There have also been many attempts to apply the topology optimization method to crashworthiness optimization problems [17, 18], and to apply the multidisciplinary design optimization methodology to crashworthiness optimization problems with other physical domains [19, 20].

The equivalent static loads method for non-linear static response structural optimization (ESLSO) is an optimization method proposed to solve various structural optimizations of a non-linear static system [21]. ESLSO uses linear sensitivity information to perform the structural optimization instead of non-linear sensitivity information. In previous research, it has been proved that the final design from ESLSO satisfies the Karush–Kuhn–Tucker necessary condition, and that the linear and non-linear sensitivity information is the same at the optimum [22]. The guarantee and non-guarantee cases of convergence of ESLSO have been discussed, and converged solutions can be found in adapting the move limit strategy in the case of the non-guarantee cases [23, 24]. The non-linear response optimization problem is converted to a series of linear response optimization with equivalent static loads (ESLs). Linear response optimization is advantageous in cost owing to the simplicity and convenience of linear structural analysis. However, ESLSO has a disadvantage because separate generation methods are needed to generate necessary responses. Therefore, a modified ESLSO is needed when it is applied to a crash problem with various types of response.

As mentioned earlier, the injury to the human body and the absorbed impact energy of a vehicle should be considered in the crashworthiness of the vehicle structures. In the present research, ESLSO is modified to handle responses imposed on the strain energy and the head injury criterion (HIC). The modified ESLSO is verified through three practical examples. Design optimization of a crash box and a knee bolster are carried out to maximize absorbed impact energy while satisfying displacement constraints. Size optimization of a frontal structure of a simplified vehicle is performed to reduce head injuries. The results of the crash box and the simplified vehicle problems are compared with those of traditional optimization methods such as the RSM. Commercial software, LS-Dyna 971, is used to perform the crash analysis in this problem [25], and ABAQUS is utilized to perform the initial stress analysis [26]. Commercial software such as GENESIS 10.0 and NASTRAN are utilized to calculate the equivalent static loads and to perform linear static response optimization [27, 28]. A program is developed with C and FORTRAN languages to interface the software systems [29, 30].

sec.title: 2 Equivalent Static Loads Method for Non-Linear Static Response Structural Optimization (ESLSO)
2.1 Conventional formulation of crashworthiness design optimization
sec.p: The formulation of crashworthiness optimization can be expressed as follows [12, 31].

where M is the mass matrix and C is the damping matrix, which are the functions of the design variable vector b. K is the stiffness matrix, which is the function of the design variable vector b and the nodal displacement vector. f(b) is the objective function and
f
t
is the external load vector.
z
·
is the velocity vector and
z
··
is the acceleration vector. The subscript N means that the response is obtained from the crash analysis. bL,k and bU,k are the lower and upper bounds of the kth design variable, respectively. The constant q is the total number of time steps. The constants l and m are the numbers of the constraints and design variables, respectively. Crashworthiness optimization can have many time-dependent constraints. As shown in equation (1d), the total number of time-dependent constraints is
q × l
. Therefore, the number of constraints increases extremely considering the time domain.

Equation (1c) is the governing equation of the crash analysis. The equation contains mass and damping effects. The damping model affects the velocity of nodes, and the mass matrix model represents the acceleration of the nodes. As mentioned earlier, crash analysis is performed for calculating the crashworthiness of the structure under the test conditions for occupant safety. Crashworthiness of the vehicle structure means the ability to absorb impact energy and be survivable for the occupant. The aims of crashworthiness optimization are to increase the crashworthiness of the structure and to achieve a lightweight body while satisfying the crashworthiness constraints. To achieve these goals, indices for calculating the crashworthiness of the vehicle structure are defined and the indices are used as the objective function f(b) or the constraints
g
j
t
( b ,
z
N
t
)
in equation (1). The indices are related mainly to the absorbed impact energy and injury of the occupants. In this research, optimization methods to solve the crash problem formulated in equation (1) are proposed.

sec.title: 2.2 Concept of equivalent static loads
sec.p: Equivalent static loads are defined as the static loads for linear analysis which generate the same response fields in linear static analysis as those of non-linear dynamic analysis at an arbitrary time. Figure 1 illustrates the concept of equivalent static loads. An equivalent load set is made for each time step of non-linear dynamic analysis. The linear static response from the ith equivalent static load (the si load case in Fig. 1) is the same as the non-linear dynamic response at the ith time step. Therefore, the total number of time steps is equal to the total number of equivalent static load sets, and the profile of the static responses which are calculated from linear static analysis using equivalent static loads is exactly the same as the dynamic response profile from non-linear dynamic analysis. The equivalent static loads of the ith load case, si, are used as external forces in linear response analysis, and the response is the same as the response of non-linear dynamic analysis at the ith time step, ti. The linear static response from the ith equivalent static load is the same as the non-linear dynamic response calculated by the governing equation (1c) at the ith time step. Therefore, the nodal displacements of the ith time step, which are calculated by equivalent static loads, contain the damping and mass effects of the ith time step, ti. The optimization process using the equivalent static loads consists of two parts: the analysis domain and the design domain. Non-linear analysis is carried out under the given loading conditions in the analysis domain. Based on the results of the analysis domain, the equivalent static loads are evaluated. In the design domain, linear response optimization is performed with the equivalent static loads, and the design is updated. The entire optimization process iterates between the analysis domain and design domain until the convergence criterion is satisfied. A conventional linear response optimization algorithm can be utilized to perform optimization in a non-linear system by using ESLSO.

caption.p: Concept of equivalent static loads at every time step

sec.title: 3 Crashworthiness Design Optimization Method Using Equivalent Static Loads
sec.p: Crashworthiness design optimization methods to solve the crash problem formulated in equation (1) are proposed. ESLSO is modified to solve crash problems, which have responses imposed on the strain energy and the HIC as formulated in equation (1). The modified ESLSO methods will be explained in the following sections.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Calculation of strain energy response using equivalent static loads
sec.p: As defined in section 2.1, a method to calculate the absorbed impact energy of a vehicle structure is needed to solve crash problems. Additional parts to minimize the transferred impact energy to the interior space of the vehicle are generally installed. The parts should absorb the impact energy with the maximum deformation with respect to the external impact. The strain energy response is usually used to calculate the absorbed energy. Therefore, a method to consider the strain energy is needed to apply the ESLSO to a crash problem.
Strain energy density U0, which is called the strain energy per unit volume, is calculated in the FEM as follows
where σ and ε are the stress and strain vectors in unit volume, respectively. Equation (11) can be transformed into a linear system without initial stress and strain as follows
The total strain energy U of the element can be calculated through volume integration using equation (11) in the FE theory, as follows
where V is the volume of the element.

Equation (13) is used to calculate the strain energy in applying ESLSO to crash problems. The equivalent static loads for stress and the equivalent static loads for strain are used to generate the strain energy response using the equivalent static loads. The strain energy response using equivalent static loads is not a genuine response value but an artificial value which is generated by a combination of the two different response values. In order to generate the artificial strain energy value, adjusted stress
σ
^
L
in equation (8) is used as stress response σ in equation (13), and adjusted strain
ε ^
L
illustrates the flow chart of the structural optimization using ESLs for the strain energy objective function. In general, strain energy response is used as the objective function to increase the absorbed impact energy of the structure. The dotted rectangular area in Fig. 2 is the outer function program for calculating the strain energy automatically with the design change in the linear static optimization process.

caption.p: Flowchart of the structural optimization using equivalent static loads for strain energy response

sec.title: 3.1.2 Calculation of the strain energy in a shell element
sec.p: Many different types of element are defined for FE analysis [8]. Of the element types, shell element is defined by the shell theory and widely used. It is not easy to apply equation (13) to the modified ESLSO in the case of the shell element because of the complexity of the shell element formula. In this section, the strain energy in a shell element is derived [32, 33].

Figure 3 illustrates the deformed shape of a shell element. The sizes of each side of the shell element are a and b, and the thickness of the element is t. ξ, η, and ζ are the local coordinates of the element. R1 and R2 are the radii of curvature of each direction in bending.

caption.p: Deformed shape of the shell element: (a) isometric view; (b) side view

sec.p: dS2 with respect to the local coordinate ζ can be described as follows
In orthogonal coordinates, the differential of the volume is equal to the product of the differential of the length of the three coordinates
According to equations (13) and (15), the strain energy in the shell element is calculated as follows

Figure 4 shows the stress and strain fields of the shell element in local coordinate ξ. In general, maximum stress and strain occur in the top and the bottom parts of an element. Values except the ones from the top and the bottom parts are linearized for volume integration in order to obtain strain energy. The linearized stress and strain can be expressed as a function of ζ as follows

caption.p: Stress and strain distribution in a shell element (1-direction)

sec.p: By using equation (17), the strain energy of local coordinate ξ, U1, can be expressed as follows
Similarly to equation (18), U2 and U12 can be derived.

sec.title: 3.2 ESLSO for head injury criterion
sec.p: As defined in section 2.1, a method is needed to calculate the injury of passengers of the vehicle structure to solve crash problems. Various types of index to calculate injury have been developed and used based on the part of the body which it is intended to measure. The indices measure reaction force to the body of a passenger or the value of acceleration applied to the body parts. Also, deformation of the body parts with regard to an external force is measured and the measured value is used as a body injury index. Head, neck, chest, knee, thigh, etc. are usually measured for the body injury indices. Of the body injury indices, the HIC is mainly used because a head injury can influence the safety of the passenger.

The head is intimately associated with life in humans. In 1972, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration proposed the HIC to assess head injury potential in automobile crash-test dummies based on the Wayne State Tolerance Curve and the Gadd Severity Index [2, 34, 35]. HIC is defined as follows

where
t
2
−
t
1
≤ 15 ms ( or 36 ms )
and a is the resultant acceleration of the head’s centre of the gravity in units of acceleration due to gravity (g = 9.81 m/s2). t1 and t2 are the time points during the crash at which HIC is the maximum.

HIC is calculated through an integration of the resultant acceleration of the head’s centre of the gravity. In ESLSO, it seems that consideration of acceleration response is nearly impossible because linear static response optimization cannot consider the velocity and the acceleration in the time domain. However, a simple finite difference method can be used for the calculation of the velocity and the acceleration responses in the time domain. By using the finite difference method, the velocity and the acceleration responses are calculated as follows

where
z
·
i
and
z
··
i
are the velocity vector and the acceleration vector at the ith time step, respectively.
z
i − 1
, zi, and
z
i + 1
are the displacement vectors at the
i − 1
th
, ith, and
i + 1
th
time steps, respectively. Δt is the size of the time step. According to the size of the time step, the accuracy of the velocity and acceleration values are determined. Therefore, it is important to determine the size of the time step.

In ESLSO, the displacement vectors at every time step are calculated from linear static response analysis with equivalent static loads. The velocity and accelerations are defined by the displacement vectors of the adjacent load cases in linear response optimization. In linear static optimization, the HIC response is considered by using the acceleration response vector which is calculated through equation (19). Figure 5 presents the flowchart of the structural optimization using equivalent static loads for the HIC objective function. The dotted rectangular area in Fig. 5 is the outer function program for automatically calculating the HIC value with the design change in the linear static optimization process.

caption.p: Flowchart of the structural optimization using equivalent static loads for HIC response

sec.title: 4 Examples of Crashworthiness Design Optimization Using Equivalent Static Loads
sec.p: Example problems are solved to validate the proposed crashworthiness optimization method. Three practical structural examples using the FEM are demonstrated. They are a crash box design problem with regard to the RCAR test conditions, the knee bolster design problem with 22 design variables, and optimization of an automobile frontal structure with respect to the HIC response.

LS-Dyna 971 is used to perform the crash analysis in this problem [25] and ABAQUS is utilized to perform the linear stress analysis [26]. GENESIS 10.0 is utilized to perform linear static response optimization [27] and NASTRAN DMAP is used for calculating the equivalent static loads [28]. A program is developed with the C language to interface the software systems. As explained in sections 3.2 and 3.3, the outer function is developed with the FORTRAN language to calculate the strain energy value and the HIC value automatically. In the outer function, LS-PrePost is used to calculate the HIC value with the acceleration information [36].

sec.title: 4.1.1 Design formulation
sec.p: As a practical example, the crashworthiness optimization of the crash box is performed by using the ESLSO. The crash box is usually installed between the bumper and the side rail to absorb the impact energy in the RCAR test condition. RCAR (Research Council for Automobile Repairs) is an international organization working towards reducing insurance costs by improving automotive damageability, repairability, safety, and security [4]. The objectives of RCAR are to evaluate the cost of the motor insurance for insurers and to make motor vehicles safer, less damageable, and more cost-effective to repair after an accident occurs.

Figure 6 illustrates the FE model of the crash box with the simplified RCAR test condition. The material property of the crash box is SAPH440 and the material property of the side rail is SPFC590 [37]. The material properties are a type of steel. The rigid wall, which is half the weight of the entire vehicle, moves towards the crash box with an initial velocity. All degrees of freedom at the end of the side rail are fixed. The crash box has an octagonal sectional shape constructed by three plates. The role of the crash box is to absorb as much impact energy as possible and prevent the interior parts of the vehicle from being damaged. The optimization formulation considering the above is as follows

caption.p: FE model for designing the crash box

mml:mrow.mml:mtext: the strain energy of the crash box

sec.p:
The design variable is the thicknesses of the crash box. The objective function is the strain energy at a specific time. The magnitudes of the displacements that should be less than the allowable displacement are the constraints. The allowable displacement
d
1
allow
is set to prevent damage of the radiator, and the allowable displacement
d
2
allow
is set at a small value to hinder the collapse of the side rail.

sec.title: 4.1.2 Comparison of results and discussion
sec.p: Figure 7 shows the optimization history of the objective function and the maximum violation of the constraints. As shown in Fig. 7, the objective function is increased by 5.9 per cent compared with the initial model while the constraints are satisfied within ten cycles. In verifying the optimum solution of ESLSO, the results of ESLSO are compared with those of the traditional optimization method using the surrogate model. It is better that ESLSO is compared with the optimization results from the gradient-based method. However, in the case of a crashworthiness problem, the results of crash analysis have oscillation and noise as mentioned above. The non-linearities and oscillation of the crash analysis responses make it difficult to calculate the sensitivity information which uses the results of non-linear analysis directly. Therefore, optimization methods using the meta-model are widely used for solving the crashworthiness problem. A wide variety of meta-models have been developed: RSM, Kriging, radial basis function, and multivariate adaptive regression splines [10]. According to how a fitting curve to sampled data is generated, meta-models are classified into regression models and interpolation models.

caption.p: Optimization history of the crash box using ESLSO

sec.p: The RSM is a typical regression model in which the unknown coefficients are estimated by means of the least-squares method, while the others are interpolation models such that a fitting curve passes exactly through the sampled points. Since RSM and Kriging models are widely used for solving the crashworthiness problem, the formulated optimization problem is also solved by the two methods. A successive response surface method (SRSM) which is installed in the commercial software LS-OPT is used to solve the problem [13, 38]. SRSM is a modified method of general RSM. The approximation function uses quadratic terms and the selection of candidate points uses the D-optimal method [39]. The response function of the Kriging meta-model consists of two terms, which are the regression model term and the stochastic term. The former represents the global model and the latter the uncertainty of the meta-model. The commercial software PIAnO is used for Kriging modelling and to perform the global optimization process [40]. A Latin hypercube model is selected for DOE (design of experiments), and 30 sampling points are determined as an appropriate number to build the trust model through rounds of several trial and error [41]. A micro genetic algorithm is used to perform the global optimization on the approximated function [42].

Table 1 shows the comparison of the optimized results of ESLSO with SRSM and Kriging. The optimum strain energy values are similar and the constraint is active at the optimum of both methods. While 11 crash analyses are required in ESLSO, 57 crash analyses for SRSM and 31 crash analyses for the Kriging method are required with the confirmation analysis. It is verified that the proposed ESLSO can find a reasonable local optimum with a small number of crash analyses. The number of iterations for the ESLSO is 11, because only a single non-linear analysis can be performed at each iteration. In the case of SRSM, the number of iterations is eight and seven non-linear analyses are required at each. In the Kriging method 30 non-linear analyses for building the meta-model are performed. The use of meta-models can be more advantageous if multiple computers are available. However, the optimum results of the meta-model may not be exact because an approximated model is utilized. Moreover, in the meta-model method, the number of function evaluations is increased geometrically when the number of design variables is increased.

caption.p: Comparison of the results for the crash box

sec.title: 4.2.1 Design formulation
sec.p: This example is the crashworthiness optimization of a knee bolster. The knee bolster is usually installed between an instrument panel and a cross-member. The role of the knee bolster is to absorb the impact energy as much as possible and to reduce knee injury in an accident [43]. Figure 8 shows the FE model of the knee bolster system [44]. In designing the knee bolster, a simplified subsystem model is developed based on the sled test model in Fig. 8(a). As shown in Fig. 8(b), the subsystem model has the knee bolster, cross-member, instrument panel, and simplified knee forms. The material property of the knee bolster is SAPH440 and the material property of the instrument panel is POLYFORT, which is a developed plastic material of polypropylene [37]. The cross-member is modelled as an elastic steel material and the knee form is modelled as a non-deformable material. The simplified knee forms moves in a direction as determined from the sled test. Using the simplified subsystem model, crashworthiness optimization of the knee bolster is carried out.

caption.p: FE model of the knee bolster: (a) sled test model; (b) subsystem model

sec.p: The design formulation of the knee bolster is as follows

mml:mrow.mml:mtext: the strain energy of the knee bolster

sec.p: The subsystem has two knee bolster structures, and the symmetric condition is applied to them. The objective function is the strain energy. Two constraints are selected. One is a displacement constraint to prevent the knee from hitting the cross-member; the other is a mass constraint in that the mass should be less than the initial model. The design variables are the thicknesses of the knee bolster, as illustrated in Fig. 9. The knee bolster structure has 22 different parts, also shown in Fig. 9. The optimization results seem to be of little practical value, but the optimization results make the design direction of the sectional shape of the knee bolster to enhance energy absorption. The optimization results show that the proposed ESLSO can solve a crash problem with many design variables. As mentioned earlier, since the meta-model methods have a limit on the number of design variables, it is nearly impossible to solve this kind of the problem which has many design variables.

caption.p: Design variables for designing the knee bolster

sec.title: 4.2.2 Optimization results
sec.p: Figure 10 shows the history of the objective function and the maximum violation of the constraints. The maximum violation of the constraints is the value of optimization at each cycle. The objective function value is normalized by the initial model. The strain energy of the structure at the optimum increases by 13.9 per cent compared with the initial model while satisfying the constraint conditions as well. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the number of cycles is 19. Therefore, the number of crash analyses is 20. Table 2 shows the design variables of the initial and optimum models. While the meta-model methods have a limit on the number of design variables, ESLSO is not directly influenced by the increase of the number of design variables.

caption.p: Objective function and constraint violation history of the knee bolster problem using ESLSO
Thicknesses of the initial and optimum models

sec.title: 4.3 Simplified vehicle structure
sec.p: The last example is crashworthiness design optimization of the frontal structure of a simplified vehicle, performed to reduce head injury. This example is suggested in previous research to verify the SRSM algorithm, and is installed in the commercial structural optimization software LS-OPT as a practical example [13, 38]. Figure 11 shows the FE model, which includes the simplified vehicle model and the rigid pole. The vehicle parts are modelled as an isotropic and kinematic-hardening plastic model of a general steel material, and the pole is modelled as a rigid material. The rigid pole is fixed on the ground; the vehicle structure flies freely to the rigid pole with an initial velocity of 15.64 m/s.

caption.p: Simplified vehicle model impacting a rigid pole

sec.p: The HIC value should be calculated by using the dummy and not the vehicle structure. HIC is the integration value of the acceleration/deceleration information of the human body in a crash. However, the HIC value calculated by the dummy motion is difficult to consider in ESLSO because design changes of the vehicle structure cannot affect the dummy motion in a vehicle structure during the linear static response optimization process. Therefore, this example is selected because the HIC value is calculated by a point on a vehicle structure in order to confirm the possibility of the proposed ESLSO method. In general, the peak value and duration time of the acceleration pulse of the vehicle structure lead to reducing human injury. Measuring acceleration on a point in the structure could be a worst-case scenario approximation (upper bound) for the acceleration levels experienced by the crash dummy. The reason is that the dummy has freedom to move during the highest acceleration peaks to be later cushioned via the airbag.

The simplified vehicle model is optimized to minimize the maximum acceleration value of node 432, which is located on the vehicle roof structure as shown in Fig. 11, regarding the intrusion condition illustrated in Fig. 12. The acceleration value is used in the calculation of the HIC value. Figure 13 shows the design variables of the problem, and Fig. 12 presents the intrusion condition considered as the constraint. The optimization formulation considering the above is as follows

caption.p: Design variables used for the optimization

sec.p: where I is the intrusion. Two design variables are selected: one is the thicknesses of the hood, front, and underside; the other is the thickness of the bumper. ESLSO cannot handle a problem having a part with free flying motion because boundary problems occur in linear analysis. To consider the contact condition between the vehicle structure and the pole, several spring elements are added between them in applying this example to ESLSO [45].

Figure 14 shows the history of the objective function and the maximum violation of the constraints. The HIC value of the optimum model increases while satisfying the constraint conditions. To verify the optimum solution of ESLSO, the results of ESLSO are compared with the results of SRSM. Table 3 shows the comparison of the optimized results of ESLSO and SRSM. The optimum objective function values are similar and the constraint is active at the optimum of both methods. Fourteen crash analyses are required in ESLSO, and 31 analyses are required in SRSM. It is verified that ESLSO can find a reasonable local optimum with a small number of crash analyses in handing the HIC response.

caption.p: Objective function and constraint violation history of the simplified vehicle using ESLSO
Comparison of optimum results for the simplified vehicle

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: When designing the structure of a vehicle, crashworthiness of the vehicle structure should be considered to minimize passenger injuries and also to reduce the impact energy transferred. The non-linearities and oscillation of the responses make it difficult to calculate the sensitivity information. Therefore, a design method needs to be developed regarding the crash optimization problem with various responses related to the crashworthiness of the structure. To achieve this goal, a new crashworthiness design optimization method using equivalent static loads is proposed to consider the strain energy and the HIC responses.

In this research, the conventional formulation of crashworthiness design optimization is defined, along with the responses that should be considered in crashworthiness optimization. The ways to generate the equivalent static loads for the responses, the strain energy and the HIC, are proposed. Also, a program is developed with FORTRAN and C languages to interface the software systems. In order to verify the efficiency and accuracy of ESLSO, three practical structural optimization examples are introduced. They were successfully solved using ESLSO. The results of ESLSO are compared with those of traditional optimization methods such as the RSM. In the comparison, the efficiency of ESLSO is confirmed. Especially, in applying ESLSO to a crash problem, which has many design variables, ESLSO can handle that problem with a small number of crash analyses. Through the examples, ESLSO is verified to solve the crash problems efficiently.

In the simple vehicle structure example, the HIC value is calculated by the acceleration information of one node on the vehicle structure. In general, the HIC value is calculated by using the dummy and not the vehicle structure. However, the HIC value calculated by the dummy motion is difficult to consider in ESLSO because design changes of the vehicle structure cannot affect the dummy motion in a vehicle structure during the linear static response optimization process. Moreover, the accuracy of the acceleration values, which are calculated through the finite difference method, is determined by the size of the time step. Therefore, the HIC value in linear static analysis, which is obtained in modified ESLSO, is not the same as the value acquired from the crash analysis. These problems should be worked out in future work.

This work was also supported by the Research Fund of Hanyang University [HYU-2011-T].
